questions.question: To be negotiable, an instrument must contain an unconditional promise or order to pay:

options.A: Any amount determined by the parties
options.B: A fixed amount of money
options.C: Money or goods at the holder's option
options.D: A reasonable sum to be determined later

questions.explanation: For negotiability, the instrument must promise to pay a fixed amount of money. Variable interest is allowed, but the principal must be fixed. Payment in goods or services destroys negotiability. The amount must be determinable from the face of the instrument.
questions.tip: Fixed amount of MONEY. Variable interest OK, but principal fixed. Payment in goods = not negotiable.

questions.question: A check is a type of:

options.A: Promissory note
options.B: Draft drawn on a bank

questions.explanation: A check is a draft drawn on a bank and payable on demand. A draft involves three parties: drawer (who writes it), drawee (who pays it), and payee (who receives payment). A note is a two-party instrument with a maker promising to pay a payee.
questions.tip: Check = draft drawn on bank. Draft = 3 parties. Note = 2 parties (maker's promise to pay).

questions.question: An instrument payable 'to the order of John Smith' is:

options.A: Bearer paper
options.B: Order paper

questions.explanation: Order paper is payable to a specific payee or their order. It requires indorsement and delivery for negotiation. Bearer paper is payable to bearer, cash, or to no one in particular and can be negotiated by delivery alone. The 'to the order of' language creates order paper.
questions.tip: 'Pay to the order of X' = order paper (needs indorsement). 'Pay to bearer' = bearer paper (delivery only).

questions.question: A blank indorsement consists of:

options.A: The indorser's signature and the name of a specific indorsee
options.B: The indorser's signature only

questions.explanation: A blank indorsement is the indorser's signature alone with no designation of a particular indorsee. It converts order paper to bearer paper, which can then be negotiated by delivery alone. Anyone in possession of bearer paper can negotiate it.
questions.tip: Blank = signature only. Converts order to bearer paper. Special = 'Pay to X' makes it order paper again.

questions.question: A negotiable instrument must be payable:

options.A: Within 90 days
options.B: On demand or at a definite time

questions.explanation: For negotiability, an instrument must be payable on demand or at a definite time. Demand instruments are payable immediately upon presentation. Time instruments are payable at a fixed date or a fixed period after a stated date or sight. Acceleration clauses are allowed.
questions.tip: Demand (now) or definite time (future date). 'When able' or 'when convenient' = not negotiable.

questions.question: A holder of an instrument is:

options.A: Any person who possesses the instrument
options.B: A person in possession of an instrument payable to bearer or to that person
options.D: Anyone who has paid value for the instrument

questions.explanation: A holder is a person in possession of an instrument that is either payable to bearer or, if payable to an identified person, is that person. Being a holder is prerequisite to being a holder in due course and entitles the holder to enforce the instrument.
questions.tip: Holder = possession + instrument runs to you. Not just possession—must be proper holder.

questions.question: To be a holder in due course, a holder must take the instrument:

options.A: For value, in good faith, and without notice of claims or defenses
options.B: Directly from the maker or drawer
options.D: With a personal guarantee from the payee

questions.explanation: A holder in due course (HDC) takes: (1) for value, (2) in good faith, and (3) without notice that the instrument is overdue, has been dishonored, is subject to claims, or has defenses against it. HDC status provides protection against most defenses.
questions.tip: HDC = Value + Good Faith + No Notice. HDC takes free of personal defenses but not real defenses.

questions.question: Which of the following is a real (universal) defense that is effective against a holder in due course?

options.A: Lack of consideration
options.B: Fraud in the inducement

questions.explanation: Real defenses are effective even against HDCs. They include: forgery, fraud in the essence (factum), material alteration, incapacity (that voids the obligation), illegality (that voids the obligation), duress (physical), discharge in bankruptcy, and statute of limitations. Personal defenses like lack of consideration don't work against HDC.
questions.tip: Real defenses (FIDM): Forgery, Incapacity, Duress (extreme), Material alteration, Illegality, Fraud in factum, Infancy, Discharge in bankruptcy.

questions.question: 'For deposit only' written above an indorsement is a:

options.A: Blank indorsement
options.B: Special indorsement

questions.explanation: A restrictive indorsement limits further transfer or use of the instrument. 'For deposit only' restricts the instrument to being deposited in the indorser's account. 'For collection' is another example. Depositaries must comply with restrictive indorsements.
questions.tip: Restrictive: limits use (for deposit only, for collection). Special: names indorsee. Qualified: without recourse.

questions.question: Primary liability on a negotiable instrument belongs to:

options.A: All indorsers
options.B: The maker of a note or acceptor of a draft

questions.explanation: Primary liability means unconditional obligation to pay. The maker of a note and acceptor (drawee who agrees to pay) of a draft are primarily liable. Drawers and indorsers are secondarily liable—they pay only if the primary party fails to pay upon proper presentment and dishonor.
questions.tip: Primary: maker, acceptor (pays first). Secondary: drawer, indorsers (pay if primary defaults).

questions.question: An indorsement 'without recourse' means the indorser:

options.A: Guarantees payment of the instrument
options.B: Disclaims liability if the instrument is dishonored
options.C: Transfers the instrument to a specific person

questions.explanation: A qualified indorsement ('without recourse') disclaims contract liability—the indorser won't pay if the instrument is dishonored. However, the indorser still makes transfer warranties and may be liable for breach of warranty. This is common when agents sign on behalf of principals.
questions.tip: Without recourse: no liability on dishonor. Still makes transfer warranties (title, signatures, no defenses).

questions.question: The depository bank in a check collection is:

options.A: The bank on which the check is drawn
options.B: The first bank to receive the check for collection
options.D: The bank that pays the check

questions.explanation: The depository bank is the first bank to receive the check for collection—typically the customer's bank where the check is deposited. The payor bank is the bank on which the check is drawn (where the drawer has an account). Collecting banks are intermediaries between depository and payor banks.
questions.tip: Depository = first to receive. Payor = bank that pays (drawer's bank). Collecting = intermediaries.

questions.question: Which of the following makes a promise conditional and destroys negotiability?

options.A: Reference to a separate agreement for rights regarding collateral
options.B: Statement of consideration given for the instrument
options.C: Statement that payment is subject to the terms of another agreement

questions.explanation: A promise is conditional (not negotiable) if payment is expressly subject to or governed by another agreement. However, mere reference to another agreement for rights regarding prepayment, acceleration, collateral, or confession of judgment does not make it conditional.
questions.tip: 'Subject to' another agreement = conditional (not negotiable). 'As per' or reference = OK.

questions.question: A holder has notice that affects HDC status when the holder has knowledge that:

options.A: The maker has a checking account at a different bank
options.B: The instrument was originally issued at a discount
options.C: The instrument is overdue or has been dishonored
options.D: The payee operates a legitimate business

questions.explanation: Notice that prevents HDC status includes knowledge that the instrument is overdue, has been dishonored, has unauthorized signatures, alterations, or is subject to claims or defenses. Knowledge that an instrument was issued at a discount does not itself provide notice of defenses.
questions.tip: Notice problems: overdue, dishonored, claims, defenses, alteration, unauthorized signature. Discount alone = OK.

questions.question: A person who transfers a negotiable instrument for consideration warrants that:

options.A: The underlying transaction was fair and reasonable
options.B: All signatures on the instrument are authentic
options.C: The instrument will be paid when due
options.D: No prior holder was a holder in due course

questions.explanation: Transfer warranties include: (1) transferor is entitled to enforce, (2) all signatures are authentic and authorized, (3) no alteration, (4) no defense is good against transferor, and (5) no knowledge of insolvency proceedings. These warranties flow from each transferor to subsequent transferees.
questions.tip: Transfer warranties: entitlement, authentic signatures, no alteration, no defenses, no insolvency knowledge. Run to all subsequent transferees.

questions.question: When a bank wrongfully dishonors a check, the bank is liable to:

options.A: The payee for the face amount
options.B: The drawer for actual damages

questions.explanation: A payor bank that wrongfully dishonors an item (when the drawer has sufficient funds) is liable to the drawer for damages proximately caused by the wrongful dishonor. This can include consequential damages, damages to credit reputation, and in some cases arrest or prosecution damages.
questions.tip: Wrongful dishonor: bank liable to drawer (customer) for actual damages. Payee's remedy is against drawer.

questions.question: A bank has no obligation to pay a check presented more than:

options.A: 30 days after its date
options.B: 60 days after its date

questions.explanation: A check becomes stale 6 months after its date. A bank is not obligated to pay a stale check but may do so in good faith. A certified check remains valid until paid or the statute of limitations runs. Holders should present checks promptly.
questions.tip: Stale check: 6 months. Bank can still pay but not obligated. Present promptly to preserve recourse against indorsers.

questions.question: An oral stop payment order on a check is effective for:

options.A: 24 hours
options.B: 14 days

questions.explanation: An oral stop payment order is effective for 14 days. A written stop payment order is effective for 6 months and can be renewed. The bank must have reasonable time to act on the order. If the bank pays over a valid stop order, the bank is liable to the customer for resulting loss.
questions.tip: Oral stop = 14 days. Written stop = 6 months (renewable). Bank needs reasonable time to act.

questions.question: A person who presents an instrument for payment warrants to the drawee that:

options.A: The drawer has sufficient funds
options.B: The presenter is entitled to enforce the instrument
options.C: All indorsers will pay if dishonored

questions.explanation: Presentment warranties to a drawee who pays include: (1) presenter is entitled to enforce, (2) instrument has not been altered, and (3) no knowledge that drawer's signature is unauthorized. These are narrower than transfer warranties because the drawee can verify the drawer's signature.
questions.tip: Presentment warranties: entitled to enforce, no alteration, no knowledge of forged drawer signature. Drawee knows drawer's signature.

questions.question: Fraud in the inducement (where a person knowingly signs an instrument but is deceived about the terms of the transaction) is:

options.A: A real defense effective against all holders
options.B: A personal defense not effective against an HDC
options.C: Not a valid defense against anyone
options.D: Effective only against the original payee

questions.explanation: Fraud in the inducement is a personal defense—the signer knew they were signing a negotiable instrument but was deceived about the nature of the underlying transaction. HDCs take free of personal defenses. Fraud in the factum (deceived about the nature of the document itself) is a real defense.
questions.tip: Fraud in inducement (knows it's a note, deceived on deal) = personal. Fraud in factum (tricked into signing, didn't know it was a note) = real.

questions.question: When a bank certifies a check at the holder's request:

options.A: The drawer and all prior indorsers remain liable
options.B: The drawer and all prior indorsers are discharged

questions.explanation: When a bank certifies a check at the holder's request, the drawer and all prior indorsers are discharged. The bank becomes primarily liable. If certification is at the drawer's request, the drawer remains secondarily liable. This reflects that the holder chose bank certification over drawer's liability.
questions.tip: Holder obtains certification: drawer/indorsers discharged. Drawer obtains certification: drawer remains secondarily liable.

questions.question: If a bank pays a check with a forged drawer's signature, the loss generally falls on:

options.A: The payee who deposited the check
options.B: The payor bank that paid the check
options.C: The drawer whose signature was forged

questions.explanation: A forged drawer's signature is not effective as the drawer's signature. The payor bank, which should know its customer's signature, generally bears the loss unless the drawer's negligence contributed or the drawer failed to examine statements and report promptly (generally within 30 days).
questions.tip: Forged drawer signature: payor bank loses (should know customer's signature). Forged indorsement: depositary bank loses.

questions.question: When a check with a forged indorsement is paid, the loss generally falls on:

options.A: The drawer
options.B: The payor bank
options.C: The depositary bank or party who took from the forger

questions.explanation: A forged indorsement breaks the chain of title—no one after the forger can be a holder. The depositary bank (which took from the forger or someone claiming through the forger) bears the loss through breach of presentment or transfer warranties. The payor bank can pass the loss back up the collection chain.
questions.tip: Forged indorsement: depositary bank loses. They took from wrong person (forger). Can sue up the chain.

questions.question: A material alteration of a negotiable instrument, such as changing the amount from $100 to $1,000:

options.A: Discharges all parties from liability
options.B: Is a personal defense effective only against the alterer
options.C: Discharges parties as to the altered terms but HDC can enforce original terms
options.D: Has no effect if the alteration is obvious

questions.explanation: A fraudulent material alteration discharges any party whose obligation is affected unless they assent or are precluded from asserting the alteration. However, an HDC can enforce the instrument according to its original terms. If the alteration is negligently invited, the drawer may be precluded from asserting it.
questions.tip: Material alteration: real defense. HDC can still collect original amount. Drawer negligence may preclude defense.

questions.question: Under the shelter rule, a person who takes an instrument from an HDC:

options.A: Must independently qualify as an HDC
options.B: Acquires the rights of an HDC regardless of notice
options.C: Cannot be an HDC under any circumstances
options.D: Is liable for any defenses asserted against the HDC

questions.explanation: The shelter rule provides that a transferee acquires the rights of the transferor. A person who takes from an HDC (or from someone who took from an HDC) has the rights of an HDC, even if they personally had notice. Exception: doesn't apply to a party who was a party to fraud or illegality.
questions.tip: Shelter: take from HDC = get HDC rights (even with notice). Exception: can't shelter if you were party to fraud.

questions.question: An accommodation maker who signs a note to lend their credit to another party:

options.A: Is not liable to the holder
options.B: Has a right of reimbursement from the accommodated party
options.C: Can assert all defenses of the accommodated party

questions.explanation: An accommodation party who pays the instrument has a right of reimbursement from the accommodated party. An accommodation maker is primarily liable to holders (same as any maker) but has recourse against the person accommodated. The accommodation party's liability can't be avoided by showing they received no benefit.
questions.tip: Accommodation party: liable to holder (can't avoid by showing no consideration). Has recourse against accommodated party.

questions.question: Payment of a negotiable instrument discharges all parties if paid by:

options.A: Any indorser
options.B: A party with no right of recourse against others

questions.explanation: Payment discharges all parties when made by a party who has no right of recourse on the instrument against others. This is typically the maker of a note or acceptor of a draft. Payment by a secondary party (indorser) only discharges parties subsequent to them, not prior parties they can seek recourse from.
questions.tip: Final payment by maker/acceptor (no recourse) = all discharged. Payment by indorser = only later parties discharged.

questions.question: A payor bank must dishonor or return a check by its midnight deadline, which is:

options.A: 12:00 a.m. the day after presentment
options.B: Midnight of the next banking day after presentment
options.C: 5:00 p.m. the same day as presentment

questions.explanation: A payor bank must dishonor or return a check by its midnight deadline—midnight of the next banking day following presentment. If the bank misses this deadline, it becomes accountable for the item (final payment) unless exceptions apply (fraud, same-day settlement, warranty claims).
questions.tip: Midnight deadline: midnight of next banking day after presentment. Miss it = bank accountable (final payment).

questions.question: An agent who signs an instrument without indicating agency status or the principal's name:

options.A: Is not liable on the instrument
options.B: Is personally liable on the instrument
options.C: Creates liability only for the principal

questions.explanation: An agent who signs an instrument without indicating agency status or the principal's name is personally liable. Proper execution requires showing the representative capacity and the principal's identity. If either is missing, the agent may be liable, though parol evidence may be used in disputes between immediate parties.
questions.tip: Agent signing: show principal's name + representative capacity. Missing either = agent personally liable to third parties.

questions.question: A cashier's check differs from a regular check because:

options.A: It can only be drawn for amounts over $10,000
options.B: The bank is both the drawer and the drawee

questions.explanation: A cashier's check is drawn by a bank on itself—the bank is both drawer and drawee. This makes the bank primarily liable. Unlike personal checks where the drawer's account balance is uncertain, a cashier's check is backed by the issuing bank's credit and is considered equivalent to cash.
questions.tip: Cashier's check: bank draws on itself (primarily liable). Certified check: bank accepts customer's check. Both = bank liable.

questions.question: Taking an instrument as security for an antecedent debt constitutes:

options.A: No value, so HDC status is unavailable
options.B: Value sufficient for HDC status
options.C: Value only if the debt is paid in full

questions.explanation: Value for HDC purposes includes taking the instrument as security for or in payment of an antecedent claim. This differs from contract law where past consideration is not valid consideration. Taking as a gift (no consideration at all) does not constitute value for HDC purposes.
questions.tip: HDC value includes: antecedent debt, security, bargained consideration. Differs from contract consideration.

questions.question: If a holder releases or impairs collateral securing an instrument:

options.A: All parties are discharged
options.B: Only the primary party is discharged
options.C: Indorsers are discharged to the extent of the impairment

questions.explanation: If a holder unjustifiably impairs collateral or releases a secondary obligor (like a guarantor), any indorser or accommodation party who has a right of recourse against that security or party is discharged to the extent of the impairment. This parallels suretyship principles.
questions.tip: Impair collateral/release guarantor: indorsers discharged to extent harmed. Same as suretyship discharge.

questions.question: If there is a discrepancy between the amount written in words and the amount in figures on a check:

options.A: The check is void
options.B: The figures control

questions.explanation: When the amount in words and figures differ, the words control. Words are considered less susceptible to alteration than figures. However, if the words are ambiguous, handwritten terms prevail over typewritten, and typewritten over printed.
questions.tip: Words > figures. Handwritten > typed > printed. These rules resolve ambiguities.

questions.question: Final payment of a check occurs when:

options.A: The check is deposited
options.B: The payor bank pays in cash, settles without right to revoke, or fails to revoke by midnight deadline

questions.explanation: Final payment occurs when the payor bank: (1) pays in cash, (2) settles for the item without right to revoke, or (3) fails to revoke a provisional settlement by its midnight deadline. Once final payment occurs, the payor bank cannot recover from collecting banks absent breach of warranty.
questions.tip: Final payment: cash payment, irrevocable settlement, or midnight deadline passes. Bank can't recover after (except warranty breach).

questions.question: Under Check 21, a substitute check is:

options.A: An electronic file that replaces physical checks entirely
options.B: A paper reproduction of an original check that is the legal equivalent
options.D: A check signed by an agent

questions.explanation: The Check Clearing for the 21st Century Act (Check 21) allows banks to create substitute checks—paper reproductions meeting specific requirements that are the legal equivalent of the original. This facilitates electronic check processing while maintaining paper records when needed. The bank that creates a substitute check warrants it meets legal equivalence requirements.
questions.tip: Check 21: substitute check = legal equivalent of original. Enables electronic processing. Banks make transfer warranties.
